Summertime joy will appear.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Sitting on the curb
response:
,

Sitting on the curb,
I watch the world go by,
Cars and buses, people hurrying,
Underneath the vast sky.

Children playing, laughter ringing,
A cat strolling by with grace,
The wind whispers secrets,
As it dances with the leaves’ soft embrace.

An old man walks with a cane,
Smiling at memories,
A young girl with a puppy,
Wagging his tail full of glee.

Time passes slowly,
Yet flies by so fast,
Each moment fleeting,
A treasure of the past.

In this place of contemplation,
My thoughts drift and roam,
The city's heart beats strongly,
In the rhythm of its own.

Sitting on the curb,
I feel life’s flow,
In this simple, quiet moment,
Everything feels aglow.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Identity: A Sonnet
response:
Identity: A sonnet of shattered mirrors
In which we search for parts of ourselves.
As shattered mirrors do, we scatter,
In trying to make sense of ourselves.

A fragmentation of one identity,
Which is a puzzle to understand.
Trying to complete the picture, we seek,
And yet, we are torn and scattered.

As the pieces lay strewn in a million places,
We realize we are the sum of these.
And as we gaze back on our reflection,
We search for what we were meant to be.

With pieces laid out in a perfect alignment,
We realize we are just fragments of ourselves.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: The God who brought you up to this extent,
response:
...

The God who brought you up to this extent,
Who made your fields and valleys green and bright,
Who measured stars, and started the sun’s descent,
Who gathers clouds like children at twilight—
He knows your heart, and the brokenness it bears,
Each tear that falls, each sorrowful lament;
He bears you up upon eternal wings,
As He guided Israel to her tent.

You cry, “Lord, where are You?” and feel forsaken,
But know He has not left you alone,
For He has promised by grace, not forsaken,
That He’ll never leave you, nor be unknown.

For even as the sparrows fall to ground,
Or thistles bloom in meadows far away,
The same is true of you, for you are bound
To Him whose heart and love are boundless as the day.

So lean on Him, His strength you will obtain,
For He upholds you, He will never fail,
In darkness and in light, in joy and pain,
The God who brought you up to this extent, will ever uphold His faithful.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
response:
...

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen my days and left me bare,
In its swift flight, what chances have we seized,
What dreams have fled, with nary a care.

The rose has bloomed and the petals fallen,
Seasons have passed in fleeting dance,
How many joys have we made our own,
And how many failures have advanced.

In the mirror’s gaze, the lines etched deep,
Reflect the tales of life’s grand sweep,
Yet still we yearn for moments yet unmet,
And seek the path we do not keep.

With wisdom's touch, the soul matures,
And eyes grown old do brighter gleam,
The hours lost are but the seeds of gain,
For in their loss, true value’s seen.

So let us treasure each sunlit morn,
Each twilight’s softly falling light,
For soon enough, Time's subtle hand will guide,
Us through the gateway of the night.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: She's shallow and easily programmed.
response:
Use alliteration and some metaphors.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
In a life of leaden limitations,
Her loveliness lies locked in limits,
Lured by trivialities,
As she skims the surface,
She misses metaphors in motion,
Manipulated by meaningless messages,
Mentally molded and manipulated.

She's silent,
As the chattering crowd crescendos around her,
She sleeps,
As the world's soul stirring songs swell,
She slips,
Through the shallow streams of status,
Stumbling,
In the stifling sentiments of society.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: And when, in the city in which I love you,
response:
...

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The streets are filled with shadows of the night,
The lights of cafés flicker and the breeze blows through
The cobblestones, where memories take flight.

There, under the starry, smoky glow,
I wander, lost in thoughts of you alone,
Each silent moment echoes with your face,
The city’s charm is simply not unknown.

I miss the scent of your hair in the rain,
Your laughter echoing through the avenues,
The warmth of your hand when we walk in vain,
And city lights, they sing our sweet delusions.

So many corners where we met and met,
Each alley held a tale of love’s design,
And as I wander in this city, I find
Your presence haunts these streets, and you are mine.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Paper neatly folded by his coat
response:
,

Paper neatly folded by his coat,
Under a tree, he sat.
In his life, he had no rule of note,
Save the one which said to love and be free.
A blue sky, a grey pigeon flying,
The wisdom in the leaves, it seemed to say,
He knew that life was fleeting as the breeze,
And youth's chuckles would soon take their leave.
So he wrote his letter, in lines plain and true,
Of his dreams and his struggles and his friends,
And as the day wound to a close,
He whispered his thoughts to the breeze.
And the breeze carried them to those who cared,
In twists and twirls and endless loops.
The night stars sparkled as he fell asleep,
His heart free of secrets, for now, was complete.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: IT is the dead of night:
response:
No stars above; but in the east. (by William Sharp, 1885)

IT is the dead of night: No stars above; but in the east,
A faint and wanly glimmer stirs the sky,
As if the sun, retreating to his rest,
Would leave a faint and dying memory,
A silent whisper of the coming morn,
When darkness shall give way to light anew.
In this brief moment, ere the dawn's return,
The world is still, in quietude profound,
Save for the rustling leaves, the whispering breeze,
Which sing a lullaby to Nature's soul,
As twilight's fingers trace the distant fields,
And shadows dance in gentle, eerie waltz.
Yet, in this silence, there is no true rest,
For heart and mind are stirred by deepest fear,
As ghosts of memories and futures grim,
Unbidden, rise to haunt the darkest night,
Their spectral fingers reaching for the soul,
And in their grasp, the human heart does shake.
But hark! The east is brightening now with light,
A promise of the morning's golden touch,
And through the dark, a single ray of hope,
Frees the enslaved heart from fear's cruel hold,
And in the sun's embrace, the world awakes,
With every eye turned to the dawn anew.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
response:
...

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
In a world where shadows are kind,
Away from the sunlight’s piercing eye,
And the noise that never does subside.

In a room where memories are dim,
Where silence reigns and thoughts unwind,
She yearns to find a quiet place,
To escape the world's unyielding pace.

Her heart a heavy stone in her chest,
In the quiet, she can think and rest,
Away from the chaotic stream,
Where the echoes of despair still seem.

With soft whispers of the moon's gentle glow,
She weaves dreams where nothing’s amiss,
And though the world may think her hid,
In her refuge, her spirit will rise.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: In my first sleep
response:
,

In my first sleep,
I dreamt a whale, emerald green,
sailing into the city,
towering tall,
like a metropolis’ ill-kept secret.
A blue fin, flipping a taxi
as if it was a child’s toy.
The buildings swayed,
people danced and sang.

I woke to rain
and chuckles,
stolen kisses on the train,
and city clouds-
an opal sky
and phantom elephants.

I tried to sleep again,
but could not,
for the whale’s song-
a lullaby to the surf,
where the city streets
meet the sea,
was all I heard,
reminding me
of where
we truly
belong.

A mighty creature,
a mountain of green scales,
who rode the waves
of our dreams.
Who reminded us
to dance
and be reckless,
to live, breathe,
and to let the city breathe us,
while in its tumbling, ecstatic
dream,
a blue fin whale
danced.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Light breaks where no sun shines;
response:
hope endures.

Light breaks where no sun shines; hope endures,
In hearts that bear the weight of endless nights,
Where shadows weave a veil of silent tears,
Yet courage whispers through the darkest fates.

In chambers deep where solitude resides,
Where dreams are woven from the threads of fear,
Light dances softly, warms the icy cold,
A beacon fierce in eyes that never yield.

Through storm and tempest, love remains a torch,
A guiding star that pierces through the gloom,
A testament to life's enduring dance,
In every heart, a hope-filled, silent song.

The path is long and often lost and bleak,
But hope remains an endless, steady flame,
Unbroken by the burden of despair,
It shines a path, for hope is ever true.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
response:
,

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call,
Of distant lands and beaches far,
The seas will sing, and mountains call,
I must embrace a roamer’s star.

These dreams have roots so deep within,
They tug and pull and never rest,
A wanderer’s song, a gypsy’s kin,
I’ve tried to quell, but none the best.

The sandy trails that lead astray,
And islands hid where storms have played,
Forgetting all the bonds of day,
The call of freedom’s song is laid.

From flitting sun to silver moon,
Through jungles dark and deserts’ cry,
I’ll sail across the ocean’s tune,
Or where the rivers wander high.

The roads are winding, skies unknown,
But in this heart there is no fear,
I’m not alone, nor all forlorn,
A wanderer’s path is crystal clear.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: As king fishers catch fire, dragonflies draw flame;
response:
...

As king fishers catch fire, dragonflies draw flame,
Their wings ablaze, a momentary fame.
In fields of wildflowers, they dance and they soar,
A fleeting ballet where the wind does explore.

The sunbeams sparkle on their iridescent skin,
Refracting light, making shadows spin.
They hunt with precision, a fierce and graceful dance,
In the air, they reign in a world of chance.

So delicate, yet so strong and sure,
Their lives an echo of the kingdom's allure.
Beneath the surface, hidden deep and true,
A tale of nature that's forever new.

May we too, with joy, our purpose find,
To soar and dance in colors bright, entwined.
For though our time is fleeting, bright and fast,
Our legacy, like dragonflies, will last.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Let the night sleep
response:
quietly

Let the night sleep quietly,
Under a cloak of stars above,
Whispers of the wind softly,
Lullaby of dreams I'm lovin'.

The crickets sing a rhythm,
As the night is closed in green,
The moon is painting colors,
To dreams, where time's unseen.

In shadows deep and darkest,
The mysteries of life we find,
If you should listen closely,
The night will whisper truth in kind.

A realm where dreams can wander,
Where secrets come alive,
Whispers of the mysteries,
Lingering deep in you and I.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
response:
...

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
In fields of gold and green did play,
Her laughter bright as morning dew,
Her spirit fierce as thunder's hue.

She'd wake at dawn, the day would greet,
With chores to do, and crops to meet,
Yet in her heart, a fire burned,
A passion fierce, where none had turned.

She loved her life, the land, the soil,
The toil, the sowing, and the soil,
But deep within, a call was stirred,
A yearning deep, a voice ensnared.

For she was strong, and she was free,
And so she dreamed of more to be,
A world where women could be bold,
And in the fields of change, be told.

A farmer's wife, with dreams aflame,
In fields of gold, she'd often came,
A legend in her own right, true,
The courage that she knew, it grew.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Depression is a fight
response:
,

Depression is a fight,
A battle within a mind,
A war that robs you of light,
A darkness that can seem never to end.

It steals your strength, your courage,
It drowns your laughter in a sound,
Of endless echo, it longs to drag you to the edge,
Where you stand alone, unwanted and afraid.

But do not forget, you have the power,
Within your heart, you have a force,
A strength unseen, a will to conquer,
A light within that's always worth the course.

You must break free, though it may take time,
Believe in yourself, stand up tall,
Remember that you are not alone,
That you are stronger than you fall.

So keep fighting, every day,
Against the storm, against the cold,
Your struggle is your story, a beautiful tale,
One of hope and healing, brave and bold.

For you are worthy, you are loved,
Your life is precious, as the sun above,
So hold onto hope, let your spirit soar,
The darkness will fade, you will never be ignored.

Depression may be a fight,
But it's one you can overcome,
With courage, with love, and a strength,
That's strong enough to start again.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: The Junes were free and full, driving through tiny
response:
towns

The Junes were free and full, driving through tiny towns,
where ice cream stands would trickle freshness into our hearts.
We'd make those short-lived stops, humming the songs of summer,
on routes unplanned and the miles untamed, dreams unfurled.
In summer dusk, the distant sunsets painted skyward hues,
as green fields and red barns marked the landscape’s steady flow.
Through windows down we'd laugh and shout, reaching out to touch
the air as miles disappeared, like lovers in a dream.

The sun would warm the car seat, skin beneath my clothes,
but up ahead the twilight brought cool into the night.
Our eyes, they reflected all the skies in soft despair,
but when we came upon the lake’s vast expanse, we'd call it home.
So long as all this driving in June we’d let it play,
we found ourselves free, with smiles that told the story true.
Of youth and summer time, with dreams in tow and spirit high,
The Junes were free and full, and every mile a song.
